title: God's Covenant with Noah
shortSummary: Genesis 9 records God's covenant with Noah following the flood, establishing new guidelines for humanity and all living creatures. It includes the promise never to destroy the earth by flood again, symbolized by the rainbow, and concludes with the account of Noah's family and the consequences of Ham's disrespect.

keyCharacters.name: Noah
keyCharacters.description: The righteous man chosen by God to survive the flood; receives God's covenant and instructions for life after the flood.

keyCharacters.name: Shem
keyCharacters.description: One of Noah's three sons; he and Japheth respectfully cover Noah's nakedness after Ham's offense.

keyCharacters.name: Ham
keyCharacters.description: Noah's son who dishonors his father by seeing his nakedness and telling his brothers, leading to a curse on his son Canaan.

keyCharacters.name: Japheth
keyCharacters.description: One of Noah's sons who, along with Shem, covers their father's nakedness out of respect.

keyCharacters.name: Canaan
keyCharacters.description: Son of Ham who is cursed by Noah as a servant to his brothers because of Ham's disrespect.

definitions.definition: A farmer or cultivator of the land; Noah begins to farm and plant a vineyard after the flood.
A solemn agreement or promise between God and humanity, often marked by a sign or token.
To fill or refill the earth; in this context, it means to populate the earth again after the flood.
A sign or symbol representing a covenant or promise; here, the rainbow serves as God's token of His promise.
In biblical terms, often refers to shame or vulnerability; Ham's seeing Noah's nakedness is an act of disrespect.

outline.heading: God's Blessing and Command to Noah and His Sons
outline.description: God blesses Noah and his sons, commanding them to be fruitful and multiply, and grants them dominion over animals. He establishes dietary laws and institutes the principle of capital punishment for murder, emphasizing humanity's creation in God's image.

outline.heading: The Covenant with Noah and All Living Creatures
outline.description: God establishes an everlasting covenant with Noah, his descendants, and every living creature, promising never again to destroy the earth by flood. The rainbow is given as the sign of this covenant.

outline.heading: Noah's Sons and the Spread of the Earth
outline.description: The chapter identifies Noah's three sons—Shem, Ham, and Japheth—as the ancestors of all post-flood humanity who repopulate the earth.

outline.heading: Noah's Vineyard and Ham's Offense
outline.description: Noah plants a vineyard, becomes drunk, and lies uncovered. Ham sees his father's nakedness and tells his brothers, while Shem and Japheth respectfully cover their father without looking.

outline.heading: Noah's Curse and Blessings
outline.description: Upon awakening, Noah curses Canaan, Ham's son, to be a servant, while blessing Shem and Japheth, indicating future roles among their descendants.

outline.heading: Noah's Later Life and Death
outline.description: The chapter concludes with a summary of Noah's life span, noting he lived 950 years and died after the flood.

application: Trust in God's promises and remember His faithfulness, as symbolized by the rainbow, to encourage hope and obedience in daily life.
Respect and honor family relationships, avoiding actions that bring shame or dishonor, following the example of Shem and Japheth.
Recognize the sanctity of human life, created in God's image, and uphold justice and the value of life accordingly.
Embrace God's commands to be fruitful and responsible stewards of the earth, fulfilling His purpose for humanity.

keyVerses.text: Whoso sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed: for in the image of God made he man.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the sanctity of human life and the divine image in man, forming the basis for justice and the value of life.

keyVerses.text: I do set my bow in the cloud, and it shall be for a token of a covenant between me and the earth.
keyVerses.significance: God establishes the rainbow as an everlasting sign of His covenant never to destroy the earth by flood again.

keyVerses.text: And God blessed Noah and his sons, and said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks God's blessing and command to repopulate and steward the earth after the flood.

keyVerses.text: And he said, Cursed be Canaan; a servant of servants shall he be unto his brethren.
keyVerses.significance: This pronouncement reveals consequences of dishonor within the family and sets the stage for future biblical narratives.
